elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Helical structure in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Helical structure in complexes 1-3. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Cross-linkage of adjacent chains through hydrogen bonding in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, viewed along the [111] direction. (b) Assembly of the adjacent chains by argentophilic interaction and π–π stacking interaction, viewed along the [100] direction. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) Cross-linkage of adjacent chains through hydrogen bonding in complex 3, viewed along the [111] direction. (b) Assembly of the adjacent chains by argentophilic interaction and π-π stacking interaction, viewed along the [100] direction. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The zigzag chain in complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  The zigzag chain in complexes 4 and 5. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) The Ag⋯π interactions in complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, which link the infinite chains into a two-dimensional network. (b) The Ag⋯π and π–π interactions in complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, which link the infinite chains into a two-dimensional network. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) The Ag⋯π interactions in complex 4, which link the infinite chains into a two-dimensional network. (b) The Ag⋯π and π-π interactions in complex 5, which link the infinite chains into a two-dimensional network. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: purple: silver; light gray: carbon; turquoise: nitrogen; red: oxygen.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig5">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Three-dimensional network in complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> linked by <mml:math altimg="si3.gif" display="inline" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:msubsup>

</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  Three-dimensional network in complex 5 linked by     PF  6 -    counter anions, viewed along the b direction.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig6">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Different linking directions of consecutive L ligand leading to a helical chain (left, for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and a zigzag chain (right, for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  Different linking directions of consecutive L ligand leading to a helical chain (left, for 1-3) and a zigzag chain (right, for 4 and 5).

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A series of silver(I) complexes [AgL(X)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (X=BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>; L=di-3-pyridyl ketone) have been characterized by X-ray crystallography. Argentophilic interaction, π–π stacking, Ag⋯X interaction, C–H⋯X (X=F, O) and C–H⋯O=C hydrogen bonding contribute to different extents in the construction of helical or zigzag infinite chains.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A series of silver(I) complexes [AgL(X)]∞ (X=BF4, ClO4, NO3, CF3SO3, PF6; L=di-3-pyridyl ketone) have been characterized by X-ray crystallography. Argentophilic interaction, π-π stacking, Ag⋯X interaction, C-H⋯X (X=F, O) and C-H⋯O=C hydrogen bonding contribute to different extents in the construction of helical or zigzag infinite chains.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">During the past 15 years, rapid development in the construction of supramolecular architectures based on metal centers and organic building blocks has continuously produced coordination polymers with interesting compositions and diverse topologies, along with their potential applications in the fields of host–guest chemistry, catalysis, electrical conductivity, and magnetic materials . In the development of both solution-based supramolecules and solid-state infinite polymers and networks, the coordination motif has been recognized as an effective ingredient in the design and self-assembly of a wide variety of supramolecular aggregates . It is noteworthy that anions also play very important roles in supramolecular assembly  and crystal engineering . As is well known, di-2-pyridyl ketone is an extraordinary ligand within the family of basic building blocks for the construction of metal–organic complexes with intriguing architectures and potential applications as catalysts and advanced materials . In contrast, the ligand behavior of its positional isomer di-3-pyridyl ketone (di-3-pyridinylmethanone) remains unexplored to this date (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sc1"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the past 15 years, rapid development in the construction of supramolecular architectures based on metal centers and organic building blocks has continuously produced coordination polymers with interesting compositions and diverse topologies, along with their potential applications in the fields of host-guest chemistry, catalysis, electrical conductivity, and magnetic materials . In the development of both solution-based supramolecules and solid-state infinite polymers and networks, the coordination motif has been recognized as an effective ingredient in the design and self-assembly of a wide variety of supramolecular aggregates . It is noteworthy that anions also play very important roles in supramolecular assembly  and crystal engineering . As is well known, di-2-pyridyl ketone is an extraordinary ligand within the family of basic building blocks for the construction of metal-organic complexes with intriguing architectures and potential applications as catalysts and advanced materials . In contrast, the ligand behavior of its positional isomer di-3-pyridyl ketone (di-3-pyridinylmethanone) remains unexplored to this date ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Here we report our studies on five silver(I) complexes generated from di-3-pyridyl ketone (L) together with various monoanions, namely [AgL(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [AgL(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [AgL(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), [AgL(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), [AgL(PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), which were shown by X-ray analysis to exhibit two kinds of polymeric chains in the solid state.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Here we report our studies on five silver(I) complexes generated from di-3-pyridyl ketone (L) together with various monoanions, namely [AgL(BF4)]∞ (1), [AgL(ClO4)]∞ (2), [AgL(NO3)]∞ (3), [AgL(CF3SO3)]∞ (4), [AgL(PF6)]∞ (5), which were shown by X-ray analysis to exhibit two kinds of polymeric chains in the solid state.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

Diethyl ether was purchased from Aldrich and further refluxed over sodium and benzophenone. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification.

Elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed by the MEDAC LTD Vrunel Science Center, United Kingdom. IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet Impact 420 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets. 1H NMR spectra were measured at 300Hz with a Bruker-300 spectrometer using CDCl3 as solvent. Mass spectrometry was conducted on a ThermoFinnigan MAT 95 XL spectrometer.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of di-3-pyridyl ketone (L)

Under the protection of N2, 3-bromopyridine (1.58g, 10mmol) in 10ml anhydrous diethyl ether was added slowly into 6.3ml (10mmol) n-butyllithium (15% in hexane) in 15ml anhydrous diethyl ether at -78°C. The resulting solution was kept at -78°C for 30min, and then 1.37g (10mmol) methyl nicotinate in 15ml anhydrous diethyl ether was added slowly within 20min with vigorous stirring. After stirring at -78°C for another 30min, the solution was allowed to warm slowly to -20°C over 3h, after which it was further quenched with 15ml HCl solution in water and methanol (water/methanol/conc. HCl=5:5:1). The mixture was extracted with dichloromethane, and the combined organic extract was dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and finally concentrated in vacuo to give an orange-yellow solid. Purification by chromatography on silica-gel using ethyl acetate/hexane as the eluent gave 1.4gL as a white solid in 76% yield, m.p. 115.8-116.3°C. 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.01 (d, J=1.5Hz, 2H), 8.85 (dd, J 1=1.2, J 2=4.8Hz, 2H), 8.14 (dt, J 1=7.8, J 2=1.8Hz, 2H), 7.49 (dd, J 1=4.8, J 2=7.8Hz, 2H), IR (KBr): 1651s, 1581s, 1473w, 1416s, 1333m, 1294s, 1193w, 1143w, 1113w, 1083w, 1018w, 931m, 845w, 812w, 729s, 696m, 667w, 621w, 567w cm-1; MS m/z: 184.06 ([MH]+, 100% relative abundance); Anal. for C11H8N2O: Calcd. C 71.73, H 4.38, N 15.20; Found C 71.69, H 4.34, N 15.19.

Synthesis of [AgL(BF4)]∞ (1)

AgBF4 (40mg, 0.2mmol) and L (37mg, 0.2mmol) were dissolved in 5ml CH3OH with stirring at room temperature. A white precipitate formed immediately, which was dissolved by the addition of CH3CN. elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-Ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Crystals mounted inside Lindemann glass capillaries were used for data collection on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer operating at 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>KV and 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA using Mo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Data collection and reduction were performed using the SMART and SAINT software . An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program . All five structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the SHELXTL program package . Crystallographic data of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray crystallography

Crystals mounted inside Lindemann glass capillaries were used for data collection on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer operating at 50KV and 30mA using MoKα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at 293K. Data collection and reduction were performed using the SMART and SAINT software . An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program . All five structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package . Crystallographic data of complexes 1-5 are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The known ligand di-3-pyridyl ketone (L) was synthesized by a procedure similar to that for 2-pyridinyl-3-pyridinylmethanone as reported by Mikhura, et al. . Ligand L readily gives rise to silver(I) complexes upon reaction with various silver salts, which can be crystallized by slow evaporation of the solvent. This family of coordination polymers exhibits two structural types in the crystalline state, namely helical and zigzag chain, due to the different linkage modes that L may take. Changing of the reaction ratio between ligand L and the Ag(I) salts does not affect the structure of the polymers and leads to the same product in each case.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

The known ligand di-3-pyridyl ketone (L) was synthesized by a procedure similar to that for 2-pyridinyl-3-pyridinylmethanone as reported by Mikhura, et al. . Ligand L readily gives rise to silver(I) complexes upon reaction with various silver salts, which can be crystallized by slow evaporation of the solvent. This family of coordination polymers exhibits two structural types in the crystalline state, namely helical and zigzag chain, due to the different linkage modes that L may take. Changing of the reaction ratio between ligand L and the Ag(I) salts does not affect the structure of the polymers and leads to the same product in each case.

<ce:para view="all">In the isostructural complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the bidentate bridging ligand L and silver atom are linked alternatively to form an infinite helical chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). In each complex, five kinds of weak interactions are involved in cross-linking such chains into a three-dimensional network: argentophilic interaction , π–π stacking , Ag⋯X interaction , C–H⋯X (X=F in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, X=O in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) hydrogen bonding and C–H⋯O=C hydrogen bonding . Among these, the weak C–H⋯O=C hydrogen bonds (H⋯O 2.433<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, C–H⋯O 154.9°) occur between L ligands belonging to adjacent chains, leading to 10-membered rings that bind the chains together to form a two-dimensional network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a). In the (1 0 0) plane, the chains are also linked together by argentophilic and π–π stacking interactions (b), as well as Ag⋯X interaction and C–H⋯X hydrogen bonding (X=F in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, X=O in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). The intervening space between adjacent repeating pitches of the helical structure is filled by the corresponding counter anions. elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> comprise the same kind of infinite zigzag polymeric chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>), whose conformation is affected by the different electron donor ability of the counter anion. As observed in their crystal structures, the two-coordinated silver atom in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> takes a strictly linear conformation, whereas in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> the N–Ag–N bond angle is 165.5°. In complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, besides being coordinated by the N atoms from two independent L ligands, the silver atom also has weak interactions with O atoms from both ligand L and trifluoromethanesulfonate anions at distances between 2.747 and 3.139<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Furthermore, Ag⋯π interaction  with a Ag-centroid distance of 3.378<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å accounts for stacking of the zigzag chains into a two-dimensional network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>a), which are further consolidated by Ag⋯O weak interactions and C–H⋯O (trifluoromethanesulfonate) hydrogen bonding. In complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, Ag⋯π interaction with a Ag-centroid distance of 3.794<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, together with π–π interaction with a centroid–centroid distance of 3.739<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (b), bind the zigzag chains into a two-dimensional network. The highly symmetric PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> acts as the dominent factor in the conglomeration of the layers through C–H⋯F hydrogen bonding (H⋯F 2.471<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 2.494<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)  and Ag⋯F weak interaction (3.110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)  (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complexes 4 and 5 comprise the same kind of infinite zigzag polymeric chain ( ), whose conformation is affected by the different electron donor ability of the counter anion. As observed in their crystal structures, the two-coordinated silver atom in 5 takes a strictly linear conformation, whereas in 4 the N-Ag-N bond angle is 165.5°. In complex 4, besides being coordinated by the N atoms from two independent L ligands, the silver atom also has weak interactions with O atoms from both ligand L and trifluoromethanesulfonate anions at distances between 2.747 and 3.139Å. Furthermore, Ag⋯π interaction  with a Ag-centroid distance of 3.378Å accounts for stacking of the zigzag chains into a two-dimensional network ( a), which are further consolidated by Ag⋯O weak interactions and C-H⋯O (trifluoromethanesulfonate) hydrogen bonding. In complex 5, Ag⋯π interaction with a Ag-centroid distance of 3.794Å, together with π-π interaction with a centroid-centroid distance of 3.739Å (b), bind the zigzag chains into a two-dimensional network. The highly symmetric PF6 - anion in 5 acts as the dominent factor in the conglomeration of the layers through C-H⋯F hydrogen bonding (H⋯F 2.471Å and 2.494Å)  and Ag⋯F weak interaction (3.110Å)  ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Though the coordination mode of ligand L in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> remains invariant, its linking direction in complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> is different from that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, resulting in two kinds of infinite chains (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). In accordance with this, together with the subtle effect of the counter anions, the torsion angles of the two pyridyl rings with respect to the carbonyl group of ligand L are different in these complexes, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. Within each infinite chain, the silver atoms of complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are strictly co-linear, while the Ag⋯Ag⋯Ag angle involving three consecutive, non-bond silver atoms takes the value 75.1°, 74.6°, 70.0°, and 166.7° for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, respectively, which clearly differentiate the two kinds of chains.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Though the coordination mode of ligand L in complexes 1-5 remains invariant, its linking direction in complexes 4 and 5 is different from that in 1-3, resulting in two kinds of infinite chains ( ). In accordance with this, together with the subtle effect of the counter anions, the torsion angles of the two pyridyl rings with respect to the carbonyl group of ligand L are different in these complexes, as shown in  . Within each infinite chain, the silver atoms of complex 5 are strictly co-linear, while the Ag⋯Ag⋯Ag angle involving three consecutive, non-bond silver atoms takes the value 75.1°, 74.6°, 70.0°, and 166.7° for complexes 1-4, respectively, which clearly differentiate the two kinds of chains.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In 1994, Sommerer et al. reported a silver complex of di-2-pyridyl ketone, [Ag(C<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>, which comprises an infinite helical chain, and in 2000 Chen <ce:italic>et al.</ce:italic> reported a series of related helical complexes [Ag(C<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(X)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> (X=NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, ClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) . The present studies on complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> show that both positional isomers of dipyridyl ketone exhibit analogous coordination behavior toward silver(I) with the carbonyl group remaining intact.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In 1994, Sommerer et al. reported a silver complex of di-2-pyridyl ketone, [Ag(C11H8N2O)(NO3)]∞, which comprises an infinite helical chain, and in 2000 Chen et al. reported a series of related helical complexes [Ag(C11H8N2O)(X)]∞ (X=NO2, ClO3, PF6, ClO4) . The present studies on complexes 1-5 show that both positional isomers of dipyridyl ketone exhibit analogous coordination behavior toward silver(I) with the carbonyl group remaining intact.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The IR spectra of the present series of complexes indicate that the coordination of ligand L with silver(I) salts affect the vibration of ligand L only to a minor extent. As to the <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>(C=O) mode, ligand L exhibits a sharp and strong peak at 1651 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> show the same peak at 1653, 1653, 1651, 1653 and 1655 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of the present series of complexes indicate that the coordination of ligand L with silver(I) salts affect the vibration of ligand L only to a minor extent. As to the v(C=O) mode, ligand L exhibits a sharp and strong peak at 1651 cm-1 and complexes 1-5 show the same peak at 1653, 1653, 1651, 1653 and 1655 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, five silver(I) complexes of di-3-pyridyl ketone (L) have been successfully synthesized and their structures characterized by X-ray diffraction. Two kinds of infinite chains resulting from <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bridging of ligand L have been observed in these complexes. Weak argentophilic interactions are manifested in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> that comprise helical chains, while Ag⋯π interaction exists in complexes <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> exhibiting zigzag chains. The structural differences within this series of complexes illustrate the significance of the anion effect , as well as the interplay among various kinds of weak interactions, on the construction of supramolecular metal–organic complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, five silver(I) complexes of di-3-pyridyl ketone (L) have been successfully synthesized and their structures characterized by X-ray diffraction. Two kinds of infinite chains resulting from N,N'-bridging of ligand L have been observed in these complexes. Weak argentophilic interactions are manifested in complexes 1-3 that comprise helical chains, while Ag⋯π interaction exists in complexes 4 and 5 exhibiting zigzag chains. The structural differences within this series of complexes illustrate the significance of the anion effect , as well as the interplay among various kinds of weak interactions, on the construction of supramolecular metal-organic complexes.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of di-3-pyridyl ketone (L)

Under the protection of N2, 3-bromopyridine (1.58g, 10mmol) in 10ml anhydrous diethyl ether was added slowly into 6.3ml (10mmol) n-butyllithium (15% in hexane) in 15ml anhydrous diethyl ether at -78°C. The resulting solution was kept at -78°C for 30min, and then 1.37g (10mmol) methyl nicotinate in 15ml anhydrous diethyl ether was added slowly within 20min with vigorous stirring. After stirring at -78°C for another 30min, the solution was allowed to warm slowly to -20°C over 3h, after which it was further quenched with 15ml HCl solution in water and methanol (water/methanol/conc. HCl=5:5:1). The mixture was extracted with dichloromethane, and the combined organic extract was dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate and finally concentrated in vacuo to give an orange-yellow solid. Purification by chromatography on silica-gel using ethyl acetate/hexane as the eluent gave 1.4gL as a white solid in 76% yield, m.p. 115.8-116.3°C. 1H NMR (300MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.01 (d, J=1.5Hz, 2H), 8.85 (dd, J 1=1.2, J 2=4.8Hz, 2H), 8.14 (dt, J 1=7.8, J 2=1.8Hz, 2H), 7.49 (dd, J 1=4.8, J 2=7.8Hz, 2H), IR (KBr): 1651s, 1581s, 1473w, 1416s, 1333m, 1294s, 1193w, 1143w, 1113w, 1083w, 1018w, 931m, 845w, 812w, 729s, 696m, 667w, 621w, 567w cm-1; MS m/z: 184.06 ([MH]+, 100% relative abundance); Anal. for C11H8N2O: Calcd. C 71.73, H 4.38, N 15.20; Found C 71.69, H 4.34, N 15.19.

Synthesis of [AgL(BF4)]∞ (1)

AgBF4 (40mg, 0.2mmol) and L (37mg, 0.2mmol) were dissolved in 5ml CH3OH with stirring at room temperature. A white precipitate formed immediately, which was dissolved by the addition of CH3CN. After filtration, the solution was placed in the dark for a week to give light yellow crystals of 1. Yield: 73%. Anal. for C11H8BF4N2OAg: Calcd. C 34.87, H 2.13, N 7.39; Found C 35.03, H 2.16, N 7.42. IR (KBr): 1653s, 1585s, 1477w, 1419m, 1333m, 1298s, 1196w, 1119s, 1080s, 1034s, 931m, 843w, 814w, 721m, 698m, 671w, 623w, 525w cm-1.

Synthesis of [AgL(ClO4)]∞ (2)

This complex was obtained as light-yellow crystals in a similar manner as for 1 by the reaction of AgClO4 with L. Yield: 80%. Anal. for C11H8ClN2O5Ag: Calcd. C 33.75, H 2.06, N 7.15; Found C 33.80, H 2.05, N 7.17. IR (KBr): 1653s, 1585s, 1477w, 1419m, 1333w, 1298s, 1143s, 1113s, 1088s, 1022w, 933w, 842w, 814w, 729m, 698m, 671w, 627m, 571wcm-1.

Synthesis of [AgL(NO3)]∞ (3)

AgNO3 (34mg, 0.2mmol) and L (37mg, 0.2mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solvent of 3ml CH3CN and 3ml CH3OH with stirring at room temperature. The solution was stirred overnight in the dark, filtered, and allowed to stay in the dark for two weeks to give light-yellow crystals of 3. Yield: 77%. Anal. for C11H8N3O4Ag: Calcd. C 37.31, H 2.28, N 11.86; Found C 37.23, H 2.25, N 11.82. IR (KBr): 1651s, 1583s, 1416s, 1383vs, 1294s, 1193w, 1115w, 1020w, 930w, 841w, 823w, 729m, 698m, 669w, 621wcm-1.

Synthesis of [AgL(CF3SO3)]∞ (4)

This complex was synthesized in the same way as for 1 by the reaction of AgSO3CF3 with L. Yield: 63%. Anal. for C12H8F3N2O4SAg: Calcd. C 32.67, H 1.83, N 6.35; Found C 32.82, H 1.83, N 6.32. IR (KBr): 1653s, 1585s, 1475w, 1417m, 1333m, 1294brs, 1174m, 1117w, 1082w, 1034s, 935m, 843w, 813w, 760w, 729m, 698m, 646m, 575w, 519wcm-1.

Synthesis of [AgL(PF6)]∞ (5)

This complex was prepared using the same method as for 1 by the reaction of L with AgPF6 in 1:1 molar ratio. Yield: 82%. Anal. for C11H8F6N2OPAg: Calcd. C 30.23, H 1.85, N 6.41; Found C 30.26, H 1.88, N 6.30. IR (KBr): 1655s, 1585s, 1477w, 1419s, 1335m, 1298s, 1250w, 1203w, 1117w, 1022w, 937m, 835brs, 731s, 698m, 671w, 621w, 559scm-1.

processes.quenching solution: 15 mL HCl solution in water and methanol (water/methanol/conc. HCl=5:5:1)
